text: Fatima is a child of war at three years
old she's too young to understand why
her countrymen turned their guns on each
other but not too young to bear the
scars she was seven months old when a
tank shell tore through her uncle's home
in northwestern Syria the fire that
followed crippled her right hand legs
and vocal cords 60% of her body was
burned her father went from hospital to
hospital pleading for doctors to save
her life
Murphy one of the hospitals suggested
giving Fatima a lethal injection they
said her burns were too severe that
she'd be disabled for her whole life now
when I look at her I thank God that
she's alive and she makes us feel happy
just by seeing her a renowned German
surgeon heard her story and decided that
it could have a happy ending professor
Marita
iseman climb was instrumental in
bringing Fatima and her family to
Germany she's now being treated at
Regensburg University Hospital to
operate on a child that is heavily
underweight she has a weight of a
one-year-old child but we cannot break
much longer because she we want her to
walk as soon as possible the doctors
here have decades of experience they
even for them this is not an everyday
operation the surgeons are conducting
several procedures today they want to
heal some of the scars on plat on his
face and test to see if they can help
her hair grow back but the main aim is
to help her walk again they're
correcting the position of her foot and
using steel pins like these to keep it
in place if all goes well they hope that
she will be able to start walking after
three months three hours later the
operation is finished doctors say it
will be some time before they can
determine its success it's not only that
the mechanics are corrected now but it's
also the psychology of being able to
stand on her feet and to climb and
use the feet and to start working so we
don't know yet for now Fatima's wounds
have been reopened her mother hopes the
tears are worth it
we will work together God willing and I
hope she will be in the best position
with her Fatima has suffered so much as
a child Fatima will remain in hospital
for many weeks she'll receive
physiotherapy and psychological support
doctors hope to operate on a hurricane
in the new year there will be more pain
ahead but the worst is now behind her
Rickon midi thea BBC news
Regensburg
